awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the effects of grandparents on the outcomes of their adult grandchildren, independent of parental influences.  Correlations due to genetics and family culture that may confound these effects also are taken into account.  This will give a more thorough analysis of social mobility than that obtained solely on the basis of parent-child relations.  This project will enhance the well-being of society by increasing understanding of the degree and pattern of intergenerational transmission of disadvantages and advantages in key sociodemographic outcomes, which affect the well-being of individuals, families, and society as a whole.

This project eliminates bias due to unobserved multigenerationally-correlated endowments through use of data on five generations available in the Utah Population Database and an innovative modeling strategy. Causal effects of parents and grandparents on children are assessed across six major sociodemographic outcomes: schooling attainment, occupation, age at marriage, age at first birth, number of children, and age at death. The project makes four contributions.  First, models of multigenerational relations that incorporate controls for unobserved multigenerationally-correlated endowments will be developed and estimated. Second, measurement error biases will be reduced by including more complete sets of members of each previous generation, up to great-great grandparents, than in prior studies. Third, the effects of sex of children and of maternal versus paternal lineage on multigenerational effects will be analyzed. Finally, the importance of cross effects, that is, effects of including many parental and grandparental sociodemographic variables, and the extent to which they reduce analytical bias will be investigated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In various disciplines of social sciences, emerging literature has attempted to assess the extent to which grandparents’ sociodemographic characteristics are directly associated with grandchildren’s sociodemographic characteristics even after taking into account parents’ sociodemographic characteristics. Evidence for direct associations between grandparents and grandchildren may suggest longer-term and more persistent influences of previous generations than those typically understood on the basis of traditional parent-child relations. However, existing literature on multigenerational associations often ignores potential heterogeneity in grandparental relations with grandchildren depending on gender and lineage of grandparents as well as gender of grandchildren. A critical limitation of existing literature to address potential heterogeneity in grandparent-grandchildren associations is the lack of data on all four grandparents.  Using the Utah Population Database that provides full information on two parents and four grandparents for over 150,000 adults, this project has assessed the associations between grandparents and grandchildren with respect to ages at first marriage and ages at first birth, net of associations with parents. Our key findings reveal that not all grandparents matter equally. In general, female parents and grandparents have stronger associations with grandchildren than male parents and grandparents. Although this pattern is observed for both female and male grandchildren, we also find that associations of female parents and grandparents are relatively stronger for female grandchildren, while associations of male parents and grandparent are relatively stronger for male grandchildren. Finally, our results also make it clear that including only one grandparent in the model, a common approach in previous studies, underestimates the associations between grandparents and children’s outcomes, compared to using information on all four grandparents. Our study has important intellectual merits on expanding the dominant model of intergenerational transmissions that exclusively focus on two generations by highlighting significant associations of grandparents with grandchildren, not totally explained by associations with parents. However, at the same time our project delivers a much more nuanced story that the grandparent-grandchild relations depend on gender of grandparents and grandchildren. In the context of rising inequality and reduced intergenerational social mobility across the globe, our project has also broader impacts on scholarly and policy efforts to understand intergenerational transmissions of advantages and disadvantages. Understanding the role of multigenerational influences and their heterogeneities is critical to policy development in addressing persistence of key socioeconomic and demographic outcomes.
